newsitem.title: USA: Dangerous insecticide implicated in NY poisonings.
newsitem.headline: Dangerous insecticide implicated in NY poisonings.

text.p: A highly controlled insecticide has been implicated in 24 cases of poisoning in New York, city officials said Friday.
Aldicarb, a potent chemical sold in the United States under the brand name Temik, is used to keep insects away from citrus, peanut and cotton crops, among other uses.

It is also the active ingredient in Tres Pasitos, a mouse and rodent poison sold illegally in New York stores in unlabelled containers, said John Gadd, a spokesperson for the city's health department. Tres Pasitos is produced in the Dominican Republic.

In the past two years, two dozen people have been poisoned after using Tres Pasitos in their homes, said Gadd. Twenty-one of those were hospitalized with symptoms of dizziness, sweating and shortness of breath, the agency reported.
"Tres Pasitos is a very strong poison which can cause serious illness, and even death, in people and pets," said City Health Commissioner Dr. Benjamin Mojica.
Doctors at New York's Poison Control Centre said the patients they had seen had probably unknowingly ingested the chemical, which looks like granulated herbs.
"We are worried people are not aware how poisonous this is," said Dr. Rama Rao, a fellow at the centre. "It doesn't come with very good instructions."

Aldicarb is so toxic that farmers who use it bury it under the soil using a special implement so that wildlife will not be exposed to it, said Albert Heier, a spokesperson at the Environmental Protection Agency in Washington. However, it leaves no residue in the crops.
The federal government has banned household use of the chemical and requires all agricultural users to register with their states, said Heier.
